ï»¿Execution Version Dated October 9, 2014 . COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is er tered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) THE GOVERNMENT OF ALSTRALIA, acting through the DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE, of Canberra, Australia (the "Government of Australia"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPF IlIl T ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, U1 /, he INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvai ii:1 Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("lIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D. 2, 433, USA (the "World Bank GroL p") (each a "Party" and together the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad internationa recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Inter -1 3t nal Organizations (1Os), the G77, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investir gi the infrastructure of Emerging N arkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to a x: 3nd access to basic services and raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic lr: wth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on 4:i ing sources of infrastructure finance-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coo cir ted effort is needed to mobilize pivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robL st pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an 1:1 s is understood to be the greates: barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investm: it (D) Governments, development linance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in e* t in developing the market for private infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand : : , in the numbers of structurally sound and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual em -:y ice of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range o pri ate investors that actively partic pate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals wil I)E lefit from collective action betwe en this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowl t dl to find solutions to complex i ifrastructure financing challenges that no single institutio i uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, the Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure F E ility Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at levera( i I( the efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruct .iie vith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prep az on, structuring, and risk mitigation for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, Ie 31F aims to complement existin(i and proposed services and initiatives currently supportec :' the Parties and other prospectivE GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepz 'ell- structured, infrastructure prciects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces: i i(i the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro re tive private sector financiers into )roject structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater Im e age of official resources in the face of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular f rge and complex projects with the potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure F E ility Partnership Program, together with other partners. 1
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended o be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set c.J: Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Foindational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their colla :ii tion, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties anc wE i other potential partners until he GIF is formally established. The final version of these objic ti as and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend tc work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fL rther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing i ilF, with a view to formally establ shing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the forec oing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to contirue t: collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the roles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each catego y b. Governance arrange-nents of the GIF; c. Operational policies 3pplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activitits and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to projict selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, incluc ic sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through t1 E ti ;e of knowledge platfon ns for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali;:ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development ban .E Ited in Annex 2 will be invited o participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF d .,: i; 1 is finalized, additional collabo ative efforts are required to develop the operational details 0i the GIF, at all times complementing existing efforts and facilities and building upon the !- red knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the l V! I of coordination between the Parties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration A rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitmen y he Parties to enter into or provice support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their cornmc 1 understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose a -r gal obligations or liabilities on any Party. 3.2 This Collaboration A rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year frory h: date thereof, unless superseded at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collabor i iN activities contemplated herei i will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' -espective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult wit * e: -h 2
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppor regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arran( ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatil,r other modification of any of tt e privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th: Parties under their constituer t documents, international conventions and any applicable la v; In witness whereof, each of the Par ies has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executE ci two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a; :r the date first set forth above. 3
ï»¿Execution Version GOVERNMENT OF AUST LIA By: E HON JOE HOCKEY M11, TREASURER OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRAL Ini 4
ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, compuising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIO 4 D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIOIAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: JI ONG KIM, PRESIDEN I 5
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 1 Preliriinary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the GIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructLre pc Jc ;ts in emerging markets and dev eloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparat : *. provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercia r institutional investor engagerient in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex pub ic-private partnerships and projects with potential for comme c viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastrL:. - 3 financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coor( in on resources in collaboration with the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of t .a v de range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructure, with the input ind ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engageme -i c uld stretch from upstream suppo t on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to dowr stream transaction preparation, financial structuring, anc risl mitigation/credit enhancemer t. 1.3 Over the longer term by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structurE:J infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset cla 3s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long t 1 assets in faster growing ecoromies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profiles 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to o >erate according to the following core principles, to be finaliz( c t on agreement among GIF partn,rs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities tl E : 'ill draw together ccmparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing put lic goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thos infrastructure prcjects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to [t=s. practice standards for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tE ch cal and financial res >urces of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mu li al ural development ins itutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in ar innovative and fl xible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve great r leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that arE beyond the reso irces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in t development and implementition of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF p, r r rs are expected to fall into one ,r more of the following categories: 6
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF w II t considered Func ing Partners. (ii) Technical Partrers-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-fundi c activities and/or )rovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity supp:Il instruments. (iii) Advisory Partnors-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial andir institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sovereign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as w l i3 other multilatera or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure prjects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparE li: optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, witl a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial arid/or institutional investment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic prograrimir g, management and use of funds, and development of operational policies and procedures; ir c hold the GIF Management U it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility', objectives and principles, witi advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compo :i i of the Governing Council will b agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is prop :iE to comprise representatives of -unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dir :t. and Chief Financial Officer o the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to .acili:E 1t: coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve Es sounding board, providing gL idance and support for GIF Management, and in particular w 1:1 view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be administered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate :E .m established for this purpose Ithe GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will f -::n as a coordinating body as projects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then moN toward technical support anc financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in i ,i ual projects. 4.2 GIF activity impleme itation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical PartnE institutions, coordinated by tl e GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmE -1 is according to specific project 'equirements and the project origination processes. Compos ti : of the implementation teams m ay vary according to the need of individual projects and gove rn iints. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection ciiteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follo\ii1 principles: (i) Development Impact-projects that support the development goals of the Gl1 partner institutions; (ii) Alignment-pro ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities a31 strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr)jects that require multiple parties to come together to provid structuring, arrar ging and financial support, and/or projects which require a b| 'ac of financial instrum ants; and 7
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial la 'ility, leverage public f inds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- M. h as through Publi -Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's se vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastracture investments that have global public good characteristi :5 uch as climate friendly-project3 that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisioi :) infrastructure services; and t ade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconnE:. Vi y and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppcrt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, witZ asw to complementing the resour:.es and support already available from partner entities and o h:r funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following a< tw es, corresponding to major proje-t development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; pro ect definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility sc 3:w ng; and legal, regula:ory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparati )n and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and P 1P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, anc design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangiig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financ n; packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies- ncluding in particular the management of environmental and 3:<: al impacts and risks, and transr arency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastr.ii :t -e projects in supporting sustair able, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements ,r external implementing entitie under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an ar proach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards anc It er standards and policies, and c evelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for G Technical Partners who are Expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activitie,, 8

European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legal Ti -. tion Programme, and the proposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('I: ') d. European Investment Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC); e. Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facil t.; f.
